RECD. AUG 14 1900
Stark

FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 247 A

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 8. }

HEADQUARTERS DEPT. OF WESTERN CUBA,
Quemados, August 2, 1900.

1. Private George W. Hinton, Light Battery A, 2d Artil-
lery, having been tried by a general court-martial convened
at Columbia Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of drunken-
ness and disorderly conduct, to the prejudice of good order
and military discipline, in violation of the 62d Article of
War; and absence without leave, in violation of the 32d
Article of War (three previous convictions), was sentenced
“To be confined at hard labor, under charge of the post guard,
for one (1) month, and to forfeit ten (10) dollars of his pay.”
The sentence is approved, and will be duly executed.

2. Private James Wilsen, Light Battery A, 2d Artillery,
having been tried by a general court-martial convened at
Columbia Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of conduct to
the prejudice of good order and military discipline, in vio-
lation of the 62d Article of War; and absence without
leave, in violation of the 32d Article of War (six previous
convictions), was sentenced “To be dishonorably discharged
the service of the United States, forfeiting all pay and allowances
due him, and to be confined at hard labor at such post as the re-
viewing authority may direct, for three (3) months.”

The sentence is approved, and will be duly executed at
Columbia Barracks, Cuba.

3. By direction of the Secretary of War, as contained in
telegraphic instructions from Headquarters Division of
Cuba, dated August 1, 1900, Commissary Sergeant Paul
Elchinger, U. S. Army, is relieved from duty at Trinidad,
Cuba, and will proceed at once to Cardenas Barracks and
report to the commanding officer of that post to relieve
Commissary Sergeant William J. Browne, U. S. Army.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation, and the Subsistence Department will
commute the rations of Commissary Sergeant Elchinger for
one day, in advance, it being impracticable to provide for
his subsistence during this journey in any other way.

4. Private Samuel J. Jump, Company L, 2d Infantry, left
on the departure of his regiment as a patient in the Military
Hospital at Matanzas, Cuba, will be sent by the command-
ing officer, Hamilton Barracks, Matanzas, to Havana in
time to join the Battalion of the 1st Infantry which will
proceed on transport “Crook” to the United States about
August 6th. Private Jump will be attached to the 1st In-
fantry until arrival in the United States, when he will be
sent to the proper station of his regiment.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation, and subsistence as far as New York
will be provided on the transport.
5. A board of officers, to consist of:

Major George M. Dunn, Judge Advocate, U. S. Volun-
teers;
Captain A. N. Stark, Assistant Surgeon, U. S. Army;
Acting Assistant Surgeon Freeman Allen, U. S. Army;

will assemble at these headquarters at such times as may
be necessary, at the call of the president thereof, for the
purpose of examining into and reporting upon such claims
as may be referred to it from these headquarters for com-
pensation for damage done to personal property through
disinfection or destruction necessary to prevent the spread
of yellow fever.
Report will be made by the board of each case separately.

6. Leave of absence for one month is hereby granted 1st
Lieutenant William Newman, 1st Infantry, to take effect as
soon as the Surgeon at Pinar del Rio Barracks removes the
quarantine existing against Lieutenant Newman and his
family.

With the approval of the Division Commander, permis-
sion is granted to go beyond the limits of the Division.

7. Complying with instructions contained in an endorse-
ment from Headquarters Division of Cuba, dated August 1,
1900, a board of survey, to consist of:
Captain E. E. Gayle, 2d Artillery;
Captain George F. Barney, 2d Artillery;
2d Lieutenant W. W. Hamilton, 2d Artillery;

will convene at the Depot Commissary, Havana, at 10
o'clock A. M., Monday, the 6th instant, or as soon there-
after as practicable, to examine into, report upon and fix
the responsibility for the damaged condition of certain sub-
sistence stores, public property for which Captain P. Moth-
ersill, Depot Commissary, is responsible, and which prop-
erty was previously ordered reported upon by a board of
survey convened by Special Orders No. 123, Headquarters
Department of Havana, 1899, but the proceedings of said
board were never completed, owing to two members being
ordered from the Island of Cuba.

8. Private Ed. Twomey, Troop D, 7th Cavalry, having
reported for duty at these headquarters from furlough, is
hereby detailed on special duty as messenger.
